description.text:
See if the circle on the bridge comes out ok!
Struts are hollow to speed printing.
My test with this show me that I must print bridges slowly!

1) print
2) observe bridge
3) adjust bridge settings
4) goto 1 unless great
5) observe quality of circle
6) fine-adjust bridge settings
7) goto 1 unless excellent
8) ???
9) profit!

comments.text: Thanks for the awesome test. After tuning my PID settings and Bridge settings my first print of this was perfect. So happy right now, Thank you!!!
comments.author: Nayen

comments.text:
Hello,
My first question when I read you comment is : how have set your PID and Bridge settings ?
For a newbie DIYer a link for the method will be fully appreciated because unless everyone wrote : "I do it with these PID, speed, etc, etc, ... " the chances that all match and have the absolute same result is far closely to 0.
3D printing has too much parameters at the same time to be science like 1 + 1 = 2 to explain it as simply as possible.
So your explanations (or links) will be very welcome. Regards.
comments.author: Nayen

comments.text: This is how I found the PID guide that I used: http://bfy.tw/Cybn
comments.author: ZobiOneKenobi

comments.text:
Thank a lot !
The first link, make feel little ninny ;-), but it was my first reaction ... I would surely finish make the same search in an other situation.
My Anet A2 motherboard kit has PID from the manufacturer that seems working not soo bad, and my skill to build it was also acceptable to print succesfully my first object at the first time :-)) ... (Only the general shape and aspect was visually a great success)
But now, I see that I'm at the very begining of a long way of non stop-curve learning, although the subjects have well been cleared by many pioners. Regards.

comments.text: Sag is when the temperature is too high and the plastic is drooping because it is too liquid. Lower the temperature at 2 degree increments. You'll know the temperature is too low if the plastic is not sticking on the ends.
comments.author: MiksPrusa

comments.text: You can also try increasing your bridge acceleration and speed. I get better results with ABS when I increase bridge speed and better with PLA when I lower it and use a fan. YMMV

This is a adapter for the Eachine FPV. The screw holes for Eachine are 27mm apart while most other drones use 18-22mm sized holders. This simple adapter changes one size to the other, while staying clear of the stuff sticking out of the backside of the Eachine camera board.
The screw holes might need to be drilled up depending on how accurate your printer is. Use 1.5mm drill to do this, as 2mm will leave the screws loose in the hole.
Updated 26.01.16: After printing I noticed the cable sits rather tight towards the hole in the middle. I increased the size of the hole in v3. Everything else looked fine.
Updated 27.01.16: Often times it helps to actually highlight the object when exporting. Fixed file.

author: xrez

title: Spools holder for BiB ONE 3D printer

description.text:
Yes, my BiB ONE is still alive :)
And this is one of my New Year resolutions: finally solve the problems with filament spools. I use 2 types of spools: small spool is 19cm diameter, big is 30cm.
This holder is designed to be compatible with both types. BOM:
  • M6 x 40mm - 4 pcs
  • M6 x 70mm - 2 pcs (I used 70mm of M6 threaded rod)
  • M6 nut - 6 pcs (or 8 pcs)
  • M6 washer - 16 pcs
  • 6x13x5mm bearing - 8 pcs

  • 6x19x6mm bearing - 16 pcs

  • M4x70mm hex key screw - 3 pcs
  • M4 nut - 3 pcs
    • Greetings for Krzysztof Dymianiuk :)

author: xrez

title: Drip-Dry at 50xy for B9Creator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This accessory for B9Creator allows you to easily recover the resin lingering on the build table after a print. This item can fit inside a 50xy calibration envelope. Rabs1 did a great job with his version of the Drip-Dry and published it before me.
Normally I would just use his excellent design, however I was already working on this design when I saw his post and I needed a version for 50xy calibration. Warning:
You have to add, at least, one base layer that covers all the build envelope. You can do it in the Edit window of B9Creator.exe. (I did not add a base layer because each person prefers a different base height/shape.) If you have got any ideas to improve the design, let me know and, if possible, I will add them.

comments.text: Wow BDan, that's genius. Thanks. If you haven't published a photo with your idea on the forum yet, please do so!
comments.author: gavi

comments.text:
Hi! It's nice but I found a very simple solution for drip-dry-ing: see the space between the 2 bolts and the left side of the build table (red part), just happens to fit perfectly on the left side of the VAT. So you unscrew the Build Table from the Arm (yellow), lean the table to the left and hang it in the left side of the VAT. You may need to move the VAT a little bit left and move the Arm up a little to clear space if you have a tall print. I find this way it's more convenient for tall and large prints because they align along the length of the VAT and will drip inside it.
Cheers!
comments.author: BDan

author: gavi

description.text: I recently printed this great, compact ice scraper http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:625925 for my Polaris RZR (scaling the length a bit to fit in the glove box) and was inspired to create something that could be used for my large 3500HD pickup truck, so I designed this ice scraper that has a hole in the handle for a length of 3/4" metal conduit. Most stock ice scrapers are too flimsy and too short to clear all of the snow without approaching both sides of the vehicle, at least when you get +300" of snow a year. By using a long length of conduit and a conduit bender, I created a slight arc in the tubing that would allow me to clear most of the windshield from one side of the car. I superglued it together and used a hose clamp on the end of the printed handle to help prevent possible splitting of the scraper, due to the print orientation and possible leverage points. I chose 3/4" conduit for the handle because it's cheap, reasonably strong, and yet readily shaped if you have a bender. Yep, mine is really long, but then again, it's for a pickup truck with a full sized bed...you can of course cut your conduit handle to whatever length works for your needs. Printed in ABS at .3 layer height, 2 perim, 50% infill. It takes a fair amount of plastic...based on tolerances and how well your printer maintains integrity of horizontal holes you may need a little interior sanding.

title: Happy Eggbot and/or Baba Yaga Bot

description.text:
This is a poseable "chicken walker" style robot with two possible heads; the happy sphere head or the weird Baba Yaga house head. For best results, I print each piece at 300% size.
It works at 200% as well.
100% would require a very fine printer. My first thing!

I used Blender to model this thing, and have been printing it on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using white PLA Filament.  
I always print with Rafts and Supports, and I print at "normal" resolution.  I haven't tried fine.  
I find for best results to print the heads sideways, the leg parts laying down (so the circular parts are parallel to the print surface) and the feet standing normally.  The .thing print files are laid out this way.  
The 2x (200% scale) takes about 3 hours to print out, and the 3x (300%!) takes about 6 hours.

comments.text: Wow, great work!  he ball joints work incredibly well.  My son has a weird obsession with Baba Yaga, and is going to flip out when he sees it.

This is a wall mounting for an Intel NUC in a modern enclosure that includes space for the 2.5 drive.  Designed to ensure all of the connectors are accessible and that the cooling holes are also available.

NOTE: The cover picture is of a previous revision – I still haven't had an opportunity to take better pictures of the current version – but the two pieces still assemble the same way as shown in that picture, and pictures of this version are coming soon! This is a 122mm quadcopter frame, made for RCX 11xx, 13xx, and 14xx motors with 3" props. It is an X shape, which gives it minimal drag and maximum speed and performance! The STL for the bottom plate is as-is, but there are 8 different STLs for the top plate:
  • bb122main0 has the camera facing forward for beginners
  • bb122main15 has the camera reclined 15°
  • bb122main25 has the camera reclined 25°
  • bb122main35 has the camera reclined 35°
  • bb122main45 has the camera reclined 45°
  • bb122main55 has the camera reclined 55° (risky, not recommended)
  • bb122main65 has the camera reclined 65° (risky, not recommended)
  • bb122mainNOFPV has no camera mount, cable routing hole, or antenna tether
    • While the license I chose allows anyone to use this design commercially, you can support me, the designer, by buying a printed frame from me (USA only)! Just click here to pay ($15 for each frame, anything extra will be considered a donation unless you tell me that you want more than one frame), and within a day I will send you an email asking your shipping address, how many frames you want (if you payed enough for multiple frames), what kind of top plate you want, and what color you want.

comments.text: Hi! Sorry for the late response. Thingiverse doesn't notify me when somebody comments here. Right now I recommend the FrSky X4RSB, which has an SBus port for up to 16 channels over a single wire. However, FrSky is about to release an even more compact version of this receiver called the XSR, and I would wait for that if I were you -- it will make your build much easier. Both of those receivers are made to work with the FrSky Taranis or any transmitter with a FrSky XJT module installed. As for batteries, if you're using 3S you should stick to 800-1000mAh, and if you're using 4S you should stick to 800-900mAh.

title: Graber i3 endstops X, Y, adjustable Z

description.text: This is a compilation of the endstops for a Graber i3. The X-axis endstop is copied from luphaxio (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:765805) but I include it in here for ease of use. (I renamed it so it would group with the other endstops.) The Y-axis endstop is designed to attach to the 8mm rail and be tripped by the LM8UU bearing. Use a #6-32 x 3/4" nut and bolt to secure. (This was modeled at 10 times the correct scale due to limitations of the software I was using. So, be sure to scale it by 1/10.) The Z-axis adjustable endstop uses #6-32 nut and bolt (approx. 1-3/4"), with a spring and washer for the adjustment.

On that motor only, I've had a little bit of deforming of the plastic around the mounting screws, but not enough to cause any issues.  If you're worried, print the mounts out of ABS instead of PLA. comments.author: Robba_duck

comments.text:
The filter threads and T2 threads can be tricky to print. I've printed these in PLA on a Vertex K8400 with a 0.35mm nozzle and a resolution of 100 micron. It has a xy-tolerance of about 0.2mm. I recently purchased a Felix Pro 2 and discovered that this printer has very thight tolerance so the filter threads of this model printed on this printer are to loose.
Please let me know if you have any problems.
Also, be aware that I do no recommend using this filter wheel for astrophotography. Hanging heavy astro-equipment on this plastic filter wheel is not a good idea.

Avete mai provato a fresare qualcosa con la mitica Power Wasp EVO? Vi sarete imbattuti nel problema di trovarvi sommersi da trucioli sparati in tutta la casa, la cantina, il garage.
Ho progettato questo accessorio da montare direttamente sul collo del Proxon al quale collegare il tubo dell'aspirapolvere. Per meglio raccogliere i trucioli e stare più vicini al piano di lavoro ho previsto di montare una gonna di gomma siliconica. Questa gonna permette di raccogliere il truciolo e se anche dovesse interferire con l'oggetto da fresare non ferma il lavoro, si piega, si deforma e non viene aspirata.
Nell'intercapedine è prevista una sede per un dado di M3 al quale avvitare una vite per stringere l'accessorio sul proxon e al tempo stesso per ancorare la gonna di silicone.

This is for the "Original" Prusa i3 kit from Prusa Research. When the Y axis on the printer makes rapid moves it causes a vibration that then causes an oscillation in the Z axis. Hanging 1KG of filament on top of the printer just makes it worse. This brace attaches to the bottom rod on the back of the printer and ties it in to the top of the Z axis thereby reducing the oscillation making for a more accurate print. The idea is similar to the two items below, but differs in that the power supply on this design is attached to the side of the main frame obstructing the rod design that extends out for the original base and serves to allow for extra clearance at the back of the Y axis. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319018
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:338111

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.35 First layer, .26 all others

Infill:

40%

Notes: Printed the base in PLA and the top in ABS, but either would work fine in this application. Easier to print the large bottom bracket in PLA.
Assemble the brackets with 3/8" (10mm) threaded rods and nuts.
Open SCAD

comments.text: Excellent design. Thank you.
comments.author: thisismud

comments.text: It does make a difference.  Just to illustrate how much vibration is going on, after I installed this brace the printer would actually vibrate its self across the granite top of my desk by several inches on dense and high speed infill printing.  I have now clamped the printer to the desk and it has improved the quality as well.  I am thinking about how to improve the design as was mentioned below, you do lose print volume.
comments.author: thisismud

comments.text: Well you've sold it to me. I'll be printing a purple one at the weekend. Cheers for sharing.
comments.author: caseyz

comments.text: I have been thinking of something like that, but then have the printed part mounted to the rod like the base does now with nuts on either side and then running all the way back to the Z axis frame and having the bottom of the frame sit in a notch in the part. there is ~5mm of clearance under the frame so it should work.  That would tie the whole thing together and make it rigid.  The printed part would end up being ~130mm long, but it would loose printed in the middle so it would use less material.  I might try to draw something up if I get the time.

comments.text: Correct, you do lose some print volume, but it is only on about the rear 20% of the Y axis.  I don't see myself printing 200x200x200, therefore any especially tall objects can be printed on the center of the bed or slightly shifted forward.  I choose higher print fidelity over volume.

title: Flex Box - A wooden box with a living hinge

description.text:
This is a derivative of the Folding Wood Booklet, a great implementation of living hinges in wood.
I redrew the design and made it into a box, suitable for trinkets, cards, photos, small papers.
The hinge is quite durable, but not ineducable. I don't feel like I would wear it out with frequent use. It's also surprisingly flexible for being made of wood. 
I plan on using more living hinges in wood from now on.
Cut from 3mm wood of your choosing, glue the walls and add a elastic string to hold it shut.

title: Yong Bu-Gong Racketeers (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Once two separate species, the brutish Yong became fused over time with the intelligent Bu-Gong parasite race. Their former intellect subsumed, the host bodies of the Yong are now enslaved to the Bu-Gong hive mind, a force controlled entirely by Zero Syndicate boss, Biz Caligula, overseer of the casino-world of Revelers Den. These characters were modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! Yong Bu-Gong Wayfarer Species Stats
Attributes: STR+3 DEX+3 BUL+1 AGI+2 END-3 REA+4 PER+1 WIL+2 CRE+0 CHA+3
Adapation: [PREDATORY] The creature is built for stalking and killing prey. (STR +1, AGI +2, PER +1, Acute Sense (Scent) 2, Skill Adept (Stealth) 2)
Adapation: [WATER DWELLER] The creature is adapted to living in and out of aquatic environs. (Acute Sense (Sight) 4, Amphibious, Skill Adept (Swim) 9)
Adapation: [ADVANCED] The creature has evolved advanced cognitive abilities (REA +2, Calculative, Openness +1, Conscientiousness +1)
Adapation: [FANGS] The creature possesses a maw full of sharp teeth. (Natural Weapon (Piercing) 5)
Adapation: [HIVE-MINDED] The creature plays a valuable role in a networked community that exists and functions similar to a singular entity (members of the species do not roll for individual personality scores, taking five plus or minus the species modifier for each. Roll an additional time for each personality trait when determining the species' modifiers). (Telepathic Link, Neuroticism -4)
O.C.E.A.N.: Openness+4 Conscienctiousness+4 Extroverison+3 Agreeableness-3 Neuroticism+0

Update Feb 10, 2017
I remixed a version 2 see it here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2100690
Read the info here before looking at the new version I reference the ideas here. Update Nov 15, 16
Thanks goes to doctorjay for remixing the project so that it fits the stock versions of the Robo3D. Here's the link http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1892658 Update: 03 Feb 16
All up and running, turned out better than I expected! Fit is great and plastic stays in place extremely well. Note that I screwed the back side closed so the back does not open. I had those magnets left over from my 330mm bed upgrade and I dual purpose them for weights to hold the front plastic down, and it clings to the the two screws in the midway position for a "held open" state while working with the hot end. The pic with my finger in it is the "held open" shot. Start printing, it's now a proven project!!! Note: on drilling any plastic retaining holes, drill slow to avoid heat and you get the best holes. Extruded plastic balls up when it is heated, drills well when cool. When cutting the new threads, turn in....turn out,, repeat going farther each time. It avoids plastic cracking, splitting. recommended color is grey as it will mesh well with the color of the plastic. I used orange so that final pictures will be easy to see. Yes I will be dremel cutting off the screws later. Update: 29 Jan 16
This worked well for me. But so good that the PLA pieces I used for my cable chain slightly melted and I had a mess created by a few uncoupled connectors. Glad I only had 10 PLA pieces and the rest were ABS. I'm reprinting chain links... argh. But hey the ABS piece I was printing at the time was WARP-Free!! and looking fantastic. I've removed "this is a work in progress" as I'm happy with the results thus far. It's time for the remixes or requests for change if you have ideas. Update:
Printing with a .8mm nozzle rather than a .4mm does make the support removal a pain. Other wise a printing speed of 27 worked well. Printing faster causes rounding of the corners and makes fit bad. I loved Mike's Acrylic enclosure but I wanted my extended bed more. That left me with no options for a heated chamber until now. With $6.76 in extruded plastic, Some clear plastic sheeting, you too can have the heated chamber you want even if you used my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1154745 "True 330mm Y rails upgrade". I'm using a 6mil clear plastic that I bought 100' of from Lowes (chain of US hardware stores) to put my hot tub in my basement. People with stock beds:
If you have the standard stock bed (what's stopping you from upgrading????) you can still use this, you just need to shrink the length of the Extenders to shorten. I was making sure this works with stock the entire design time. If some one wants to help, I just need the full distance the fence should be to support the fully extended bed.
Instead of printing the 2 supports, you can cut a piece of wood (or dowel) and counter drill a pilot hole a tad smaller than 3mm to connect the sides together. You MUST print solid (100% infill) to get the stability needed AND USE SUPPORTS for all prints except the Supports. Printing with a .8mm nozzle I had issues with the supports as they were kinda hard to remove. Comments, Comments..I want to hear what you think about this.

title: Openbuilds OX CNC router Belt Tensioner

description.text:
Update 2/18/16
Updated the adjustable side of the belt tensioner. Made the hole spacing for the belt clamp wider to allow a longer screw to be used without interfering with the 10-32 screw. Also added a slight angle at the interface between the fixed and adjustable parts to essentially create a dovetail slide. Belt tensioner for the openbuilds GT2 3mm belt. it is designed to use 4 4-40 x 1/2" long screws for the belt clamps and a 10-32x1" screw for the tension adjuster. Printed with both PLA and ABS. Both seem to work pretty well. you need to lightly file the interface edges on the round adjustable slide to get it to move smoothly https://youtu.be/bXs7wBjp5aw

title: Walkera Runner 250 Advance GPS Replacement Support

description.text: This is an upgraded support for the GPS for the Walkera Runner 250 Advance.  The original one breaks almost every crash and is a real pain to fix all the time. This one is in 2 pieces.  One to get screwed to frame and the top one to mount the GPS on.  There are tabs to align each piece, where it's meant to be super-glued together.  With enough force on impact just the glue breaks free allowing you to just re-glue it over and over.  So far, it's saved me a ton of headaches gluing the original post repeatedly.

author: PowerScissor

description.text: My first test design.

A printable set of guitar picks design with the iconic alien eyes. The original files (non 075 ones) are 1.25mm thick at the tip and the 075 files are, as you guessed it, 0.75mm thick at the tip (more suitable for acoustic guitars). This set comes with a printable flying saucer stand with slots to hold one set of either size picks.
The types of picks (in both thicknesses) included are: -355
-346
-Baby 346
-351
-Jazz
-Teardrop All picks and the stand legs should be printed as solid parts
The saucer should be printed with at least 30% infill
I slightly modded LiokaiserOmega's design to fit in a slightly smaller 3d printer's tray. Love it, dude.

Using the following options: card_count = 50
image_rotation = 0

Move_Image_Left_Right = 33
Move_Image_Up_Down = 45
image_size = 56

This is my first model on Thingiverse, a cute little robot that looks a bit tired but is always happy to hold your cellphone for you.
There are 3 versions of this robot:

This is the first version, it prints in one piece and because of this it's the most solid and best-aligned version of the model.
However, it requires support between the body and the head and this support is kind of a pain to remove
In Cura you need to set support type to "Everywhere"
I printed it in PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 10% infill, 0.8 shell width and a raft - but those are probably not important.

This version uses 2 different STL files, one for the body and one for the head and eliminated the annoying support from V1 The body STL does not need support at all. You need to rotate the head STL before printing (make sure the head is flat on the bed, in Cura use the "Lay flat" option), you can print it in one of two orientations:
  • Neck up - that should print with no support
  • Face up - that will need just a little bit of support but the face will look better
    • I print both on the same bed, head face up, with support (Cura is smart enough to not generate supports for the body). The head-body connector should fits, you may need to remove the support material from the neck with a knife. The connector is designed for a 0.4mm nozzle. I printed it in PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 5% infill, 1.2 shell width and a raft - but those are probably not important.

The third version adds a little tunnel to let you pass the phone's USB cable inside the body.
It's a little bulkier (thicker legs and body) to allow room for the cable, also, with phones with large rounded corners it's less stable because the force of the USB cable pushes the phone.
The cable comes out of the robot's left side (your left when looking at the robot from the front, right from the robot's point of view), it does not fit phones where the USB connector in on the bottom, if your phone's connector is on the right you can mirror the STL.
This version uses the same head as V2, please read the head printing instructions above in the V2 section.
The body does not need any support.
I printed it in PLA, 0.2mm layer height, 5% infill, 1.2 shell width and a raft - but those are probably not important.
The model was designed in SketchUp Make and the STL cleaned up in the online netFabb

title: Fursuit- or puppet-head base - version 29 - raccoon

description.text:
This is a head-base that can be used to build a puppet-, plushie-, robot- or even a fursuit-head. Fake fur can be glued on.
The model is scaled for costume size - based on my measurements. I have a small head - you might have to scale it up if you want to use it for a costume.
This model was not made for animatronic eyelids. I did not make a model for the back of the head, ears and nose.
There are two versions of this head: fursuithead29 2 has smaller eyebrows, a relocated jaw hinge - the holes were added to make it easier to attach the fur by glueing or sewing.

author: Tioh

title: Dual E3D V6 MK8 part fan mount

description.text:
Part fan for Peter Stoneham's Rigidbot Dual V6 Mk8 Alloy Mount. Fits both version 1 & 2.
This fan mount takes advantage of the existing bearing bolts as well as the extra mount point on the far right edge (M3) to minimize sloping. Consists of two parts in order to get perfectly flat bottom parts closest to the print bed, as well as to the carriage. The parts fit together with M3 bolts and nuts - or super glue if you want to keep the weight to an absolute minimum. Uses a single 40mm fan to cool part for both extruders. UPDATE 2016-01-27 (v2B)
  • Increased distance to bed, will not hit printed parts on fast moves
  • Improved airflow with wider distribution, better downward angle
  • Centered fan in relation to print heads (X axis)
  • Centered fan in relation to mount (Y axis)
  • Stronger mount points
  • Better weight distribution
    • UPDATE 2016-01-31 (v2C)
  • Redesigned nozzle to force air more downward, away from heater block
  • Larger flat bottom area for easier printing, slightly larger air volume
  • Fixed small alignment issue on fan mounting holes

Printer:

RigidBot

Notes: For top part, no support, brim or raft is needed. 0.2mm layer height is enough, as there are no real details in the vertical plane. Bottom part should be printed oriented as in the file, using supports. 0.05-0.1mm layer height is recommended.

• If needed, drill up all reinforced/encircled holes to 3mm. Do NOT drill the four holes closest to the center where the fan will go.
  • Attach the top and bottom parts with M3 bolts through the four (drilled up) holes surrounding the fan area. fasten bolts with lock nuts on the bottom.
  • Place the 40mm fan in the center an attach with M3 bolts OR self-tapping screws. If necessary, pre-tap the four holes with an M3 tap.
  • Unfasten the left bearing bolts on the carriage, place the fan mount on top of the plate and re-fasten the bolts through the fan mount.

author: anggar

description.text:
Formerly I used as bath for my birds a cap of a butter dish. But this part crumbled more and more over the time. Because my birds are very sensitive for changes in their environment I tried to make the new bath similar to the old one. But I made some improvements. So the bottom is flat now, the volume a little bit higher and the upper edges are wider and rounded for better sitting. Size: 145 x 104 x 42 mm³ Printed with PLA crystal clear, extruder 210°C, bed 60°C It is not easy to get the bottom waterproof. I got it with the following tricks:
I used two different print parameter settings. The first three bottom layers were printed with rectilinear external fill, the next three layers with circular external fill. For the first and forth layer the nozzle fan was disabled for better connection. Additionally I increased the extrusion factor from 0.9 to 1.1. So the lines and layers are better fused and become waterproof.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

No

No

author: anggar

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the board of my recent assembled Geeetech Ix.
I will be soon uploading the walls of the enclosure.
I designed the central hole for a 40x40x10 cooler to be mounted on top of the processor and drivers.
I thought the polygons look fun and provide more than enough ventilation. You might save the M3 screws from the kit for the assemble of this enclosure. This project is still... a project, so be patient and you'll see the results For a more Robust, prooven design, check thing:1279978 out, its looks great and compact

Printer:

Geeetech Pro IX

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

15%

Notes: I printed the top enclosure in abs Chroma green with 240C and 105C with 0.2 layer using Repetier, I strongly recommend using SD card as it takes quite a while to print all the polygons (took me 3:50) and at the last layer ocurred a timeout error, so sadly I had to print it again ( so yeah, we are using a 200 buck printer, lets dance by its music).
Painters Tape (the blue one) and Acetone (ask your girlfriend if you don't know what it is) are a must! the thin and weak structure of the top will tend to warp, so go on and overkill the Brim on slicer with 8mm. For the front of the enclosure you might print it on its back, you rather clean the support of the slots with a stylus than drill and tap the m3 holes, there is plenty free space for the cables, as I wanted the cables that go to the extruder to be free as possible.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Continued:
Generation 3 (Gen3) of the Southern Pipe Fitting Method. More Updates to follow. I could make one of these, certify it to all the standards, and be 100% confident that it is safe. But that would be mine, printed on my printer, acetone vapour bathed in my coffee machine, not yours. I can't vouch for the quality of your build. That's something you'll have to do. Ok, I've not seen anyone do plumbing or pipework of practical use, so I'm claiming this as the modestly named Southern Method. Using a single material home printer and Printing the pipes at 45° WITHOUT SUPPORT MATERIAL to print bed allows finished pipe profiles to be round rather than "teardrops" shapes to prevent the materials collapsing in on itself at the top. First rule of plumbing club, you don't mess with systems you don't understand.
Second rule of plumbing club, YOU DON'T MESS WITH SYSTEMS YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND(!)
Every modification will take as long as it takes.
1 system per mod,
If this is your first night at Plumbing Club, you've got to plumb. This is intended for low pressure return pipes for grey water at approximately room temperature. Do not use on Gas (Propane, LPG, Butane, Domestic Gas supplies, or any combustable media). Do not use on hot water or central heating systems (temp >40°C ; If you do not understand what ">" or "°C" means, don't use this part!). Do not use on macerated sewage. Do not use in temps close to 0°C. Do not use under floorboards or similar situations where it cannot be seen, monitored or changed easily. This design is not suitable for use in Nuclear Power Stations or Satellite Applications. Basically, use this sensibly. I've used similar in hydroponics, and it works at low pressure (102KPa / 1ATM - if you don't know what a KPa is, or what 1 ATM is, please don't use this design). I'm saying "Grey Water Systems Only" - but that's an ass covering statement, if you feel your build is safe enough to use on other systems, I'm not your keeper. I'm just an idiot. This is a 1x2x3 "plus" cube puzzle design.
it has a simple pin mechanism to snap everything together. No additional hardware is needed.
Make sure the end pieces move freely in the grooves before assembly. The fit should be tight, but you should be able to turn them.
Assembly is easy,... place the pin into one of the center pieces. Place the four end pieces into each of the slots around that piece. Now take the remaining end pieces and place them above the first four. Finally, get the other center piece started, make sure everything is aligned, and snap it all into place.

title: "Smartrap CoreXY"-like X Carriage with internal clamping belts (gets rid of the "in-the-way" belt clamping ears)")

description.text: See in 3D how this X Carriage is going to be included into the [WIP!] 3D printer I am designing, at Sketchfab: https://skfb.ly/LPP7 WARNING: THIS "THING" IS NOT INTENDED TO BE PRODUCTION READY!! Download and modify to suit your needs.

description.header: NOTE: The solution I will go forward with has been chosen, namely the printed internal teeth. You can find the latest iteration of the design at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1505842, where I have added a tensioning system to the "earless" feature. You can see the first iteration here ("earless" only): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1369402
description.text: I wanted to start somewhere in designing a CoreXY 3D printer and SmartRap core was one highly debated at the time for its JSCAD customizer and its rapid growth. So I downloaded the package and tried to add a dual hotend, which I failed because of those ears that "catch" the belt. They also seem feeble to me and unaesthetic. Difficult to package maybe. Or I simply didn't like it just because. I set myself on a journey to achieve a similar X carriage (for vertically stacked X rods) but better (better for me that is). Currently I have 3 solutions that I am currently printing test parts of so I can decide which one is the easiest to print, easiest to clamp and maybe even tension. For the first solution I have designed a toothed surface against which the belt would be gripped inside the X Carriage block simply by inserting it through the slot at the wider gap level and sliding it down or up in between the 3D printed teeth. The second and third solutions are based on several designs I have seen online or that have been pointed to me on reprap forums (especially this one on youmagine: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/gt2-belt-clamps). They are basically using the belt's own teeth to clamp itself by routing it around another pin or round object. This will be updated as I achieve more results/ have more ideas. Update 2016/02/25: Please check http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1369402 for the STL of the X Carriage I've chosen. Update 2016/01/31: I have realized that on a CoreXY all belts always face the same direction so I have re-designed the whole thing and updated all the files here. The third solution was not suitable anymore so I have deleted it. I have uploaded two small printable parts that can be fiddled with in a CAD software to modify the distance between the teeth and the walls and also the teeth depth so that you can print it until you get a good result for belt grip. Then you can print the whole carriage (which is not uploaded yet).

comments.text: I am super interested in seeing how this works out as I have never been happy with the toothed version we have now.  It would be great if you could work out attachments for an inductive sensor and print fan too once you decide which of these three designs works best.
comments.author: Rein_Aurre

comments.text:
I am planning on working on a probe and fan attachments, as well as a direct extruder attachment too. You can see some preliminary designs on this reprap forums thread:
http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?397,615854
comments.author: Rein_Aurre
